summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) and Special Technologies and Applications Office (STAG) requesting scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein, possessed an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: Subject of FBI obstruction of justice investigation for attempting to sell an address book containing names and telephone numbers believed to belong to additional underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein, rather than turning it over to law enforcement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the employer of Alfredo Rodriguez and the central figure in a child prostitution case whose associates and potential underage victims are listed in the address book Rodriguez possessed.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division of the FBI opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Request for document conversion of telephone records
events.description: FBI Miami Division submits a formal request to the Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and process telephone records from the Rodriguez/Epstein investigation for incorporation into the Telephone Application (TA) database.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (Address of FBI Document Conversion Laboratory)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, was under FBI investigation for obstruction of justice as of October 2009.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book containing names and telephone numbers believed to belong to additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein and his associates.
Rodriguez attempted to sell the address book rather than turn it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.
The FBI was processing telephone records from this address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims, for investigative use.
The document is an internal FBI form coordinating the technical processing (scanning, OCR, data formatting) of these records for the investigation.
